453
This system has a center at the origin if and only if one of the following conditions holds
(I) A âˆ’2b = C + 2a = 0,
(II) C = a = 0,
(III) b + d = 0,
(IV) C + 2a = A + 3b + 5d = a2 + bd + 2d2 = 0.
The following result gives a short proof of the sufï¬cient conditions of Kapteynâ€“Bautin
theorem.
THEOREM 4. If system (17) satisï¬es one of the four conditions of the Kapteynâ€“Bautin
theorem, then it has a center at the origin.

Bautin theorem has a center at the origin, it is sufï¬cient to show that it has a ï¬rst integral
in a neighborhood of the origin.

4. On the degree of the invariant algebraic curves
From Jouanolouâ€™s result (see Theorem 2.1(c))) it follows that for a given polynomial dif-
ferential system of degree m the maximum degree of its irreducible invariant algebraic
curves is bounded, since either it has a ï¬nite number p < [m(m + 1)/2] + 2 of invariant
algebraic curves, or all its trajectories are contained in invariant algebraic curves and the
system admits a rational ï¬rst integral. Thus for each polynomial system there is a natural
number N which bounds the degree of all its irreducible invariant algebraic curves. A nat-
ural question, going back to PoincarÃ© [86], is to give an effective procedure to ï¬nd N.
Partial answers to this question were given by Cerveau and Lins Neto [16], Carnicer [15],
Campillo and Carnicer [12], and Walcher [101]. These results depend on either restricting
the nature of the polynomial differential system, or more speciï¬cally on the singularities
of its invariant algebraic curves.

Integrability of polynomial differential systems
455
Of course, given such a bound, it is then easy to compute the algebraic curves of the sys-
tem and also describe its elementary or Liouvillian ï¬rst integrals (modulo any exponential
factors) see for instance [73,28,84].
Unfortunately, for the class of polynomial systems with ï¬xed degree m, there does not
exist a uniform upper bound N(m) for N as shown by the system:
Ë™x = rx,
Ë™y = sy,
with r and s be positive integers. This system has a rational ï¬rst integral
H = yr
xs
and hence invariant algebraic curves xs âˆ’hyr = 0 for all h âˆˆC.
A common suggestion was that the following question would have a positive answer:
Given m â©¾2, is there a positive integer M(m) such that if a polynomial vec-
tor ï¬eld of degree m has an irreducible invariant algebraic curve of degree
â©¾M(m), then it has a rational ï¬rst integral.
See for instance the open question 2 in [31], or the question at the end of the introduction
of [65].
The purpose of this section is to present two families of polynomial differential systems
of degree 2 without rational ï¬rst integrals but with irreducible invariant algebraic curves of
arbitrarily high degree. Thus we show that no such function M(m) exists.

We will refer to this result as the Darboux lemma; it can be stated more precisely as follows.
DARBOUX LEMMA. Let K be an algebraically closed ï¬eld and let A,B,C,Aâ€², Bâ€²,Câ€² be
six homogeneous polynomials of degrees l, m, n, lâ€², mâ€², nâ€² in three variables with coefï¬-

(i) A,B,C are relatively prime and so are Aâ€²,Bâ€²,Câ€²,
(ii) l + lâ€² = m + mâ€² = n + nâ€² = r and the orthogonality relation holds:
AAâ€² + BBâ€² + CCâ€² = 0,
(26)
(iii) the homogeneous ideal (A,B,C,Aâ€²,Bâ€²,Câ€²) generated by all six polynomials has
no zero in the projective plane P2(K).
Then, the homogeneous ideals generated by the triples (A,B,C) and (Aâ€²,Bâ€², Câ€²) have
only ï¬nitely many zeroes in the projective plane.
Denoting by h and hâ€² the total multiplicities I(A,B,C) and I(Aâ€²,Bâ€²,Câ€²) of these ho-
mogeneous ideals in the projective plane, there is a relation between h,hâ€² and the degrees:

= r2 âˆ’r(l + m + n) + (lm + mn + nl).
(27)
Darboux started the proof of his result as follows
En effet, soient h le nombre des points communs aux trois courbes A,B,C; hâ€² celui des points
communs aux trois courbes Aâ€²,Bâ€²,Câ€², . . .
This original proof is wrong; in particular, Darboux paid little attention to the last hy-
pothesis (no common zeroes) and a counterexample is easy to ï¬nd. Jouanolou noticed
that Darbouxâ€™s result was wrong and established clearly the formula (27) in his book [58,
pp. 183â€“184], but his proof is far from being elementary. Jouanolou uses Chernâ€™s classes.
Here, we present one of the two simple proofs given in [24]. Later on we shall apply Dar-
boux lemma to polynomial differential equations.
In the proof that we present here we use standard facts about the intersection index of
plane algebraic curves. This proof is divided into two steps. The ï¬rst step deals with a

462
J. Llibre
special case of the statement under extra assumptions and it follows the ideas of Darboux.
The second step consists in reducing the general case to the special case in order to get the
complete result.
In this section K will denote an algebraically closed ï¬eld. It will be convenient to denote
an ideal generated in some polynomial ring over K by the elements A1,...,Ak simply by
(A1,...,Ak). Other notations and deï¬nitions will be given when they become necessary.
We ï¬rst recall some standard facts about homogeneous ideals of the polynomial ring
A = K[x0,...,xt], that have only a ï¬nite number of zeroes in the projective space Pt(K).
Let P be a point in the projective space Pt(K). The local ring OP can be deï¬ned in two
ways. First, it is the subring of the ï¬eld K(x0,...,xt)0 of homogeneous rational fractions
of degree 0 consisting of all those with a denominator that does not vanish at P . Second,
one of the projective coordinates of P does not vanish and there is no restriction in sup-
posing x0(P) Ì¸= 0 to ï¬x matters. Then the polynomial ring K[x1,...,xt] is isomorphic to
the quotient ring of K[x0,...,xt] by its ideal generated by x0 âˆ’1, and OP is the local ring
Sâˆ’1K[x1,...,xt], where S is the multiplicative set of all t-variable polynomials that do
not vanish at P .
Let P be a point of Pt(K) and let I be a homogeneous ideal of A. The ideal IP is
the ideal of the local ring OP generated by I. If the quotient ring OP /IP is a ï¬nite-
dimensional vector space over K, its dimension is called the multiplicity or the intersection
index of I at P ; IP (I) is a convenient notation for this number. In particular IP (I) Ì¸= 0
means that P is a zero of I. Thus, if I is a homogeneous ideal with a ï¬nite number of
zeroes in Pt(K), the sum I(I) = 
P IP (I) over all zeroes of I is well deï¬ned. It is called
the total multiplicity, or the total intersection index or the degree of I.
In the case of two or more three-variable homogeneous polynomials over K, A1,...,Ak
the intersection index IP (A1,...,Ak) at some point P of P2(K) can be deï¬ned as
the corresponding index for the homogeneous ideal generated by A1,...,Ak. We note
IP (A1,...,Ak) = IP ((A1,...,Ak)).
In particular, if A1,...,Ak (with k â©¾2) are relatively prime, then IP (A1,...,Ak) is
deï¬ned at every point P . On the other hand if they have a nontrivial greatest common
divisor D, IP (A1,...,Ak) is deï¬ned at all points P of P2(K) where D(P) Ì¸= 0.
Here are some standard properties of the intersection index whose proof can be found in
the book of Fulton [45]. The ï¬rst two are general:
(i) IP (A1,...,Ak) only depends on the ideal (A1,...,Ak) of A,
(ii) in fact, IP (A1,...,Ak) only depends on the ideal generated by A1,...,Ak in OP : if
B(P) Ì¸= 0, B is invertible in OP and IP (BA1,A2,...,Ak) = IP (A1,A2,...,Ak).
The next two ones are speciï¬c to the three-variable case:
(iii) If B has no nontrivial common factor with CCâ€², IP (B,CCâ€²) = IP (B,C) +
IP (B,Câ€²) (Addition formula).
(iv) If F and G are two homogeneous polynomials without nontrivial common factor,
they have a ï¬nite number of common projective zeroes and I(F,G) = deg(F) Â·
deg(G) (BÃ©zoutâ€™s theorem).
We will call a family [A,B,C,Aâ€²,Bâ€²,Câ€²] of homogeneous polynomials in K[x,y,z]
an orthogonal system of polynomials if

7. Algebraic limit cycles for quadratic systems
We recall that a limit cycle of a real afï¬ne polynomial vector ï¬elds is an isolated periodic
orbit in the set of all periodic orbits of the system. An algebraic limit cycle of degree r is
an oval of an irreducible invariant algebraic curve f (x,y) = 0 of degree r which is a limit
cycle of the system.
In 1958 Qin Yuan-Xun [88] (see also [104]) proved that quadratic systems can have
algebraic limit cycles of degree 2, moreover when such a limit cycle exists then it is the
unique limit cycle of the system. Evdokimenco in [40â€“42] proved that quadratic systems
do not have algebraic limit cycles of degree 3, for two different shorter proofs see [22,25].
We provide one of these proofs in what follows.
THEOREM 7.1. Quadratic systems have no algebraic limit cycles of degree 3.
PROOF. Let f = 0 be an invariant algebraic curve of degree 3 of a real afï¬ne polynomial
vector ï¬eld of degree 2. If the cubic curve f = 0 has multiple points, then it is rational (its
genus is 0) and there is no oval in it. If f = 0 has no multiple points, Equation (46) in the
proof of Proposition 6.2 implies hâ€² = 22 = 4. According to Theorem 6.3, the system has a
rational ï¬rst integral and thus no limit cycle.
â–¡
The ï¬rst class of algebraic limit cycles of degree 4 was given in 1966 by Yablonskii
[103]. The second class was found in 1973 by Filiptsov [43]. Recently, two new classes
has been found and in [25] the authors proved that there are no other algebraic limit cycles
of degree 4 for quadratic systems. The uniqueness of these limit cycles has been proved
in [21]. We summarize all these results into the following theorem, for a proof see the
mentioned papers.
THEOREM 7.2. The following statements hold.
(a) After an afï¬ne change of variables and a rescaling of the time variable the only
quadratic systems having an algebraic limit cycle of degree 2 are
Ë™x = âˆ’y(ax + by + c) âˆ’x2 + y2 âˆ’1,
Ë™y = x(ax + by + c),
(53)

invariant algebraic curve

of degree 2. This algebraic limit cycle is the unique limit cycle of system (18).

476
J. Llibre

8. Limit cycles and algebraic limit cycles
In this section we follow the paper [69]. In 1900 Hilbert [55] in the second part of its 16th
problem proposed to ï¬nd an estimation of the uniform upper bound for the number of limit
cycles of all polynomial vector ï¬elds of a given degree, and also to study their distribution
or conï¬guration in the plane. This has been one of the main problems in the qualitative
theory of planar differential equations in the XX century. The contributions of Bamon [5]
for the particular case of quadratic vector ï¬elds, and mainly of Ã‰calle [39] and Ilyashenko
[57] proving that any polynomial vector ï¬eld has ï¬nitely many limit cycles have been the
best results in this area. But until now it is not proved the existence of an uniform upper
bound. This problem remains open even for the quadratic polynomial vector ï¬elds.
A conï¬guration of limit cycles is a ï¬nite set C = {C1,...,Cn} of disjoint simple closed
curves of the plane such that Ci âˆ©Cj = âˆ…for all i Ì¸= j.
Given a conï¬guration of limit cycles C = {C1,...,Cn} the curve Ci is primary if there
is no curve Cj of C contained into the bounded region limited by Ci.

9. Darbouxian theory of integrability and centres
In this section we follow the paper [30]. One of the main applications of the Darbouxian
theory of integrability is proving the existence of a centre, see for instance Section 3.
In the elementary theory of qualitative differential equations we identify three main types
of behavior at a nondegenerate singular point: a node, a focus, or a saddle. All three are
stable, in that a small perturbation will not change the stability of the singular point. More-
over, topologically, we can read off their behavior from just their linear terms. However,
there is also the possibility that the singular point is a ï¬ne focus or a centre. That is, the
divergence vanishes at that point. In this case the linear terms give a centre: a neighborhood
of the origin which consists of closed trajectories. In this case, the nonlinear terms must
be examined in order to determine whether the point is stable or unstable. If it is neither
and the system is analytic, then the singular point is also a centre for the nonlinear system.
Without loss of generality, we can consider the singular point to be at the origin and to be
in the form
Ë™x = Î»x âˆ’y + p(x,y),
Ë™y = x + Î»y + q(x,y),
(74)
where p and q represent the nonlinear terms. The case of a ï¬ne focus or centre corresponds
to Î» = 0.
We can distinguish between a centre and a (ï¬ne) focus in a number of ways; we follow
the most direct ï¬rst. It can be shown that for any N there is a change of coordinates which
brings the origin of (74) to the polar form
Ë™r = c3r3 + c5r5 + Â·Â·Â· + O

rN
,
Ë™Î¸ = 1 + d2r2 + d4r4 + Â·Â·Â· + O

rN
.
(75)
If all the ci are zero up to c2k+1, then the system is said to have a ï¬ne focus of order k. The
stability is given by the sign of c2k+1.
It can also be shown that perturbations of the nonlinear terms of (74) can produce in
this case at most k limit cycles bifurcating from the origin. Furthermore, if the class of
systems (74) are sufï¬ciently general, there are perturbations which produce this number of
limit cycles in a multiple Hopf bifurcation. We call c2k+1 the kth Liapunov quantity.
If all the ci are zero, then it can be shown that there is an analytic change of coordinates
which brings the system into the polar form
Ë™r = 0,
Ë™Î¸ = 1 + d2r2 + d4r4 + Â·Â·Â·.
The singular point is obviously a centre in this case.

486
J. Llibre
Given a class of polynomial equations in the form (74), we are often interested in the sub-
class with centres at the origin. The problem is that showing that we have a centre requires
an inï¬nite number of conditions. However, if we could ï¬nd an analytic ï¬rst integral in a
neighborhood of the singular point, then the singular point must be a centre. In fact, the
linear terms of (74) implies that the ï¬rst terms of such an integral are a +b(x2+y2)s +Â·Â·Â·,
and therefore trajectories close to the origin are closed.
Alternatively, we could ï¬nd an integrating factor which is well-deï¬ned and nonzero in a
neighborhood of the singular point. In either case an obvious method for constructing such
functions is the Darbouxian theory of integrability. The surprising thing is that this method
is so successful.
THEOREM 9.1. All the nondegeneratecentres of systems (74) with homogeneousquadratic
or cubic p and q are integrable with Darbouxian ï¬rst integrals. The same is true if p and
q are of the form
p = p2 + xf,
q = q2 + yf,
where p2, q2 and f are all homogeneous quadratics.
For a proof of this theorem see [92,89,9].
The last system is the projective version of the quadratic systems and in fact was the
system studied by Darboux.
As an example of this, consider the system
Ë™x = y + a1x2 + (a2 + 2b1)xy âˆ’a1y2 + x2y,
Ë™y = âˆ’x + b1x2 + (b2 âˆ’2a1)xy âˆ’b1y2 + xy2,
generically this has 4 invariant lines, whose cofactors are all of the form
Î±x + Î²y + xy.
Hence we can conclude that the system has a centre at the origin.
Another method for distinguishing between a focus and a centre is to use a Liapunov
function. This is a function V = k + x2 + y2 + O((x2 + y2)3/2) which satisï¬es

10. Non-existence of limit cycles
This section follows the paper [30]. We rename a Liapunov function a function Ï†(x,y) for
which
DÏ† > 0

in the region of interest. Clearly the existence of such a function in a region precludes the
existence of periodic solutions and, in particular, limit cycles.
In the same way, we deï¬ne a Dulac function to be a function R such that
âˆ‚
âˆ‚x
P

+ âˆ‚

> 0.
By applying the divergence criterion, we can see that such a function also precludes the
existence of periodic solutions or limit cycles in any simply connected region where R is
well-deï¬ned and nonzero.
The analogy between these functions and the ï¬rst integrals and integrating factors ex-
amined up to now is obvious. In particular, given a collection of invariant algebraic curves
or exponential factors with cofactors Li, if we can ï¬nd constants li such that

liLi > 0,
or
div(P,Q) âˆ’

liLi > 0,
then there are no limit cycles in any simply connected region where the Darbouxian func-
tion is well deï¬ned.
For example, the Loktaâ€“Volterra equations are quadratic with two invariant lines. There
is also a singular point which does not lie on either line around which any limit cycle must
lie. Thus the cofactors of the two lines must vanish at this point. If the divergence also
vanishes at the singular point, then we can ï¬nd a linear dependency between the cofactors
and the divergence which means that the system must be integrable and we have a family
of closed orbits. If the divergence does not vanish then we can construct a Dulac function
of Liapunov function as above. Thus there are no limit cycles in either case.
The example above shows in a simple way how detailed calculations can be reduced to
simple geometric arguments instead. We could have replaced the lines above by invariant
hyperbolas or parabolas with no increase in difï¬culty.
If one of the curves was an ellipse, however, we might have problems. First, the ellipse
may be a limit cycle in its own right. Second, if the polynomial representing the ellipse
appeared to a negative power in the Dulac function, then we cannot apply Greenâ€™s theorem
since the region surrounding the ellipse is not simply connected. This can be overcome in
certain cases by considering line integrals around the loop itself.
In order to get some deeper results, we need to allow some curves which are almost in-
variant. Rather than abstract things more, we give an example which is very representative
of other results.
THEOREM 10.1. Suppose a quadratic system has an invariant algebraic curve and a sin-
gular point not on this curve where the divergence vanishes, then the system has no limit
cycles in any simply connected region of the complement of the curve.
PROOF. Any limit cycle in a quadratic system surrounds only one singular point which
must be a focus (see [104]). Suppose a limit cycle surrounds a singular point with nonzero
divergence. Let C = 0 be the invariant algebraic curve with cofactor L. Thus

Is it possible to extend these methods to prove the uniqueness of limit cycles if we allow
the Dulac function to vanish at the singular point which the limit cycle surrounds? It would
be very nice if this was true as many of the uniqueness results for quadratic systems have a
nice algebraic content. For example a quadratic system with an invariant line or an invariant
parabola have at most one limit cycle. However, no such methods are known at the moment
and other less direct methods need to be used.

LEMMA 11.5. If Cc has no repeated factors, then (Cx,Cy) = 1.

we have that x(Cc)x + y(Cc)y = cCc. So Aa|Cc. Since Aa, (Cc)x, (Cc)y and Cc are ho-

of Aa having multiplicity m, must be linear factors of Cc having multiplicity m + 1. This
last statement follows easily identifying the linear factors of the homogeneous polynomial
Cc(x,y) in two variables with the roots of the polynomial Cc(1,z) in the variable z. Hence,
Aa is a repeated factor of Cc. It is in contradiction with the assumption.

12. Elementary and Liouvillian ï¬rst integrals
We now examine the effectiveness of the Darbouxian theory of integrability, i.e., what sort
of integrals does it capture. The surprising result is that in some sense it captures every
â€œclosed form solutionâ€. However, we clearly need to make this idea precise before we can
explain the known results. Here, we follow the paper [30].
The idea of calculating what sort of functions can arise as the result of evaluating an
indeï¬nite integral or solving a differential equation goes back to Liouville. The modern
formulation of these ideas is usually done through differential algebra. The advantage over
an analytic approach is ï¬rst that the messy details of branch points etc., is hidden com-
pletely, and second that the way is open to apply these methods to symbolic computation.
We assume that the set of functions we are interested in form a ï¬eld together with a
number of derivations. We call such an object a differential ï¬eld. The process of adding
more functions to a given set of functions is described by a tower of such ï¬elds:
F0 âŠ‚F1 âŠ‚Â·Â·Â· âŠ‚Fn.
Of course, we must also specify how the derivations of F0 are extended to derivations on
each Fi.
The ï¬elds we are interested in arise by adding exponentials, logarithms or the solutions
of algebraic equations based on the previous set of functions. That is we take
Fi = F0(Î¸1,...,Î¸i),
where one of the following holds:

Integrability of polynomial differential systems
501
(i) Î´Î¸i = Î¸iÎ´g, for some g âˆˆFiâˆ’1 and for each derivation Î´.
(ii) Î´Î¸i = gâˆ’1Î´g, for some g âˆˆFiâˆ’1 and for each derivation Î´.
(iii) Î¸i is algebraic over Fiâˆ’1. If we have such a tower of ï¬elds, Fn is called an elemen-
tary extension of F0.
This is essentially what we mean by a function being expressible in closed form. We
call the set of all elements of a differential ï¬eld which are annihilated by all the derivations
of the ï¬eld the ï¬eld of constants. We shall always assume that the ï¬eld of constants is
algebraically closed.
THEOREM 12.1 (Liouville theorem). If an element f in a differential ï¬eld F is the deriv-
ative of an element g in an elementary extension ï¬eld G with the same ï¬eld of constants,
then we must have

We say that our system (1) has an elementary ï¬rst integral if there is an element u in an
elementary extension ï¬eld of the ï¬eld of rational functions C(x,y) with the same ï¬eld of
constants such that Du = 0. The derivations on C(x,y) are of course d/dx and d/dy.
THEOREM 12.2 (Prelle and Singer [87]). If the system (2) has an elementary ï¬rst integral,
then there is also an elementary ï¬rst integral of the form
v0 +

where the ci are constants and the vi are algebraic functions over C(x,y).
It is known that we cannot strengthen this theorem to make all the vi rational func-
tions in x and y. By manipulating this formula and taking traces we obtain the following
corollary.
COROLLARY 12.3. In the situation above there is always an integrating factor of the
form R1/N, with R âˆˆC(x,y) and N an integer.
Thus the method of Darboux ï¬nds all elementary ï¬rst integrals. For a direct proof of this
corollary, see [20].
Another class of integrals we are interested in are the Liouvillian ones. Here we say that
an extension Fn is a Liouvillian extension of F0 if there is a tower of differential ï¬elds as

described by closed form solutions or quadratures are the polynomial ones.

From (110) and (111) it follows that systems (106) studied by Moulin Ollagnier are
those which satisfy a(B âˆ’b)C Ì¸= 0 and c(a âˆ’A)B Ì¸= 0. Therefore, it remains to deter-
mine:
(i) Which are the Liouvillian integrable systems (106) with a(B âˆ’b)C = 0 and c(a âˆ’
A)B Ì¸= 0?
(ii) Which are the Liouvillian integrable systems (106) that cannot be written into the
form (109)? Or equivalently, what are the Liouvillian integrable systems (106) hav-
ing c(a âˆ’A)B = 0?
Now we shall determine the normal forms of the Lotkaâ€“Volterra systems (106) which can
have a Liouvillian ï¬rst integral and which have not been studied by Moulin Ollagnier.
According with the previous paragraph those systems must be systems (106) satisfy-
ing
(i) either a(B âˆ’b)C = 0 and c(a âˆ’A)B Ì¸= 0,
(ii) or c(a âˆ’A)B = 0.
In fact, case (ii) can be subdivided into the following two subcases:
(ii.1) a(B âˆ’b)C Ì¸= 0 and c(a âˆ’A)B = 0,
(ii.2) a(B âˆ’b)C = 0 and c(a âˆ’A)B = 0.
Doing the change of variables (x,y) â†’(y,x) it is immediate to check that the expres-
sions a(B âˆ’b)C and c(a âˆ’A)B are interchanged. Therefore, this change of variables
interchanges cases (i) and (ii.1). In other words, case (i) is contained in case (ii). Finally,
again due to the change of variables (x,y) â†’(y,x) to study case (ii) is equivalent to study
the case a(B âˆ’b)C = 0.
In the next proposition we reduce the study of systems (106) with a(B âˆ’b)C = 0 to
analyze the Liouvillian integrability of some subclasses of systems (106).

PROPOSITION 13.5. System (lv6) with B Ì¸= 0 has no Liouvillian ï¬rst integrals.

invariant algebraic curves of (lv6) are x = 0 and y = 0. Additionally, we shall also prove
that (lv6) has no exponential factors. Since B Ì¸= 0 a linear combination of the cofactors
of x = 0 and y = 0 cannot be equal to minus the divergence of system (lv6). Then, by
Theorem 2.1 it follows that system (lv6) has no integrating factors of the form (14) with
f1 = x and f2 = y.

ferent from x = 0 and y = 0. Suppose that f = 0 is an irreducible invariant algebraic curve

A Ck function H :U â†’R with k â©¾0 is a strong ï¬rst integral of the differential sys-
tem (123) deï¬ned in U if H is constant on each solution of this system, and H is non-
constant on any open subset of U. Here k â©¾0 means that k = 0,1,2,...,âˆ,Ï‰. More
precisely, k = 0 means that H is continuous, k = 1,2,...,âˆmeans that H is Ck, k = Ï‰
means that H is analytic. If k â©¾1 then the previous deï¬nition of integrability implies that
the derivative of H following the direction of the vector ï¬eld X is zero; i.e., if XH = 0
on U.
This deï¬nition of strong ï¬rst integral is the usual deï¬nition of ï¬rst integral which appears
in the major part of books on differential equations (see for instance [3] and [96]). With
this deï¬nition the linear differential system
xâ€² = x,
yâ€² = y,
(125)
deï¬ned on R2 has no strong ï¬rst integrals. This is due to the fact that every strong ï¬rst in-
tegral of system (125) must be a continuous function on R2 that must take a constant value
on each straight line through the origin, because these straight lines are formed by orbits of
the system. Hence it must be constant on the whole R2, consequently there are no strong
ï¬rst integrals for system (125). By using this argument it follows that if system (123) has
a strong ï¬rst integral, then it cannot have nodes, foci, centerâ€“foci, singular points having
some parabolic or elliptic sectors, limit cycles and separatrix cycles that be the Î±- or Ï‰-
limit set of some orbit of the system (see [96] for deï¬nitions). Since we do not like that
differential systems so easy as system (125) have no ï¬rst integrals, we will introduce the
notion of weak ï¬rst integral.
Let Î£ be a set of orbits of system (123) such that U \ Î£ is open. We say that a Ck
function H :U \ Î£ â†’R with k â©¾0 is a weak ï¬rst integral of the differential system (1.9)
deï¬ned in U if H is constant on each solution of system (123) contained in U \ Î£, and
H is nonconstant on any open subset of U \ Î£. If k â©¾1 this deï¬nition implies that the
derivative of H following the direction of the vector ï¬eld X is zero on U \ Î£.
We remark that the unique difference between the notions of strong and weak ï¬rst inte-
gral is that a weak ï¬rst integral does not need to be deï¬ned in the whole domain of deï¬n-
ition U of the differential system (123). This difference has been noted by many authors.
Thus, the ï¬rst integrals computed by Darboux [38] in 1878 for polynomial differential
systems possessing sufï¬cient algebraic solutions are in general weak ï¬rst integrals. If we
study the integrability of the linear differential systems
dx
dt = xâ€² = ax + by,
dy
dt = yâ€² = cx + dy,
(126)
with ad âˆ’bc Ì¸= 0 (nondegenerate), then with the notion of strong ï¬rst integral only the
centers and the saddles are integrable, but with the notion of weak ï¬rst integral all linear
systems (126) are integrable. In particular we show that system (125) has the weak ï¬rst
integral H :R2 \ {0} â†’R where H(x,y) = xy/(x2 + y2).
We claim that the notion of weak ï¬rst integral is the natural notion of integrability for
two-dimensional differential systems instead of the more usual notion of strong ï¬rst inte-
gral. Theorem 14.1 will conï¬rm this claim. In order to present it we need some preliminary
deï¬nitions and results. In this section we follow the papers [19,63].

ï¬eld X on the regular surface Î£, satisfying that the polynomials g and h are relatively
prime, and that the intersection of the surfaces {h = 0} with Î£ is transversal. If h is non-
constant, then {h = 0} âˆ©Î£ is an invariant algebraic curve of X on Î£, and g satisï¬es the
equation
Xg = gKh + hKF ,
on the points (x,y,z) of Î£, where Kh and KF are the cofactors of h and F respectively.
15.2. The surfaces
Now we describe the 2-dimensional regular surfaces on which we will study the Darboux-
ian theory of integrability for the polynomial vector ï¬elds deï¬ned on them. These surfaces
will be the quadrics and the 2-torus.
It is well known that the quadrics can be classiï¬ed into seventeen types. There are ï¬ve
types of imaginary quadrics (namely the imaginary ellipsoid, cone, cylinder, two planes
that intersect, and two parallel planes). Since in this section we only consider real polyno-
mial vector ï¬elds on real surfaces, we omit these previous ï¬ve imaginary quadrics. From
the twelve real quadrics there are three which are formed by planes (namely two planes

Integrability of polynomial differential systems
521
that intersect, two parallel planes, and a double plane). Since the study of the Darboux-
ian theory of integrability of the polynomial vector ï¬elds on these surfaces is reduced to
the classical study of the Darbouxian theory of integrability of planar polynomial vector
ï¬elds, we omit these three types of quadrics. In short we only deal with the remainder nine
quadrics.
We remark that the reduction of every quadric to each canonical form is made through
a linear isomorphism, and that a such isomorphism and its inverse are polynomial diffeo-
morphisms. Therefore, the study of the Darbouxian theory of integrability of polynomial
vector ï¬elds on these nine quadrics can be restricted to take for each of these quadrics its
canonical form. In what follows we describe the canonical forms for these nine quadrics
and their local charts, that we shall need later on. In fact we only present one local chart
for each surface, the full atlas would be described in a similar way, but it is not necessary
for studying the existence of ï¬rst integrals.

15.3. Darbouxian theory

algebraic results.

1. Introduction
The obtention of global (i.e., nonperturbational) results for the forced pendulum equation
started with the rigorous mathematical study of the periodic solutions of the periodically
forced pendulum equation
yâ€²â€² + Î±2 siny = Î² sin t
(1)
initiated in 1922 by Georg Hamel, in a paper of the special issue of the Mathematische
Annalen dedicated to Hilbertâ€™s sixtieth birthday anniversary [55].
Hamelâ€™s contribution starts by proving the existence of a 2Ï€-periodic solution of Equa-
tion (1) through the direct method of the calculus of variations. He shows that the corre-
sponding action integral

mean value zero. The Ritz method is then used to ï¬nd a ï¬rst approximation of the amplitude
of the periodic solution.
Hamel then notices that the symmetries of the equation imply that any solution of Equa-

y(0) = y(Ï€) = 0

When Î±2 â©¾1, Hamel uses Lyapunovâ€“Schmidtâ€™s method to study the 2Ï€-periodic solu-

536
J. Mawhin
So, Hamel anticipates or uses several of the fundamental methods of nonlinear analysis,
in a work which will not be essentially superseded during some sixty years.
An important role in renewing the interest to the forced pendulum equation was played
by FuË‡cik in the late nineteen seventies, when he wrote, in the Introduction of Chapter 26
of his monograph [49]:
Finally we shall present here one attempt to obtain the existence of a T -
periodic solution of the mathematical pendulum equation
âˆ’uâ€²â€²(t) + sinu(t) = f (t).
(4)
The result is not ï¬nal since the necessary and sufï¬cient condition obtained for
T -periodic solvability of (4) is not useful.
After describing very partial results in this direction and mentioning extensions personally
communicated by Dancer, FuË‡cik concluded that the
description of the set P of f for which the equation uâ€²â€² + sinu = f (t) has a
T -periodic solution seems to remain a terra incognita.
Motivated by FuË‡cÃ­kâ€™s remarks, but unaware of the existence of Hamelâ€™s paper, Castro [32]
(for Î± â©½1), Dancer [36] and Willem [129], independently (for arbitrary Î±), reintroduced
in the early eighties the use of the direct method of the calculus of variations, in the setting
of Sobolev spaces. The time was ripe for the obtention by Mawhin and Willem [85], some
sixty years after the ï¬rst one, of a second periodic solution, using a reï¬nement of the
mountain pass lemma.
At the same time, the forced pendulum equation also became a paradigm for the theory
of chaos, and appeared in the description of Josephson type junctions. We only describe
global results in this direction here, and refer to the bibliography of [82,117] for the nu-
merous perturbational and numerical aspects.
A fundamental role in the development of the qualitative theory of nonlinear differential
equations and its applications to engineering, was also played by the pendulum equation
with a constant torque or Tricomiâ€™s equation
yâ€²â€² + cyâ€² + a sin y = b,
introduced by Tricomi [125,126] in his studies of synchronous electrical machines, and
widely developed since (see [83] for references).
To keep the size of the survey reasonable and facilitate the comparison between results
obtained through different methods, we only state the theorems for the standard (possibly
dissipative) forced pendulum equation
yâ€²â€² + cyâ€² + a sin y = h(t).
Most of the assertions remain valid if a sin y is replaced by an arbitrary continuous S-
periodic function g(y) with mean value zero. Recent results depend upon the fact that
a sin y is replaced by a S-periodic function whose Fourier series contains higher harmon-
ics [63]. Also, some conclusions survive when the friction term cyâ€² is replaced by a more

Global results for the forced pendulum equation
537
general one of LiÃ©nard type f (y)yâ€² or of Rayleigh type f (yâ€²). See the references in [82]
and the recent papers [52,54].
For the same reason of brevity, we will not describe the possible generalizations to sys-
tems of pendulum-type, and in particular to the equations of the forced multiple pendulum,
and to higher order pendulum-type equations. The reader can consult the bibliography in
[82] and the recent paper [116]. We shall also leave aside the existence of forced oscilla-
tions of the spherical pendulum (which depends upon methods of a quite different nature),
considered by Furi, Pera and Spadini, and the pendulum-type equations describing the li-
bration of satellites. Again, references to the corresponding literature for those questions
can be found in [82].
Let us mention also that the corresponding problem for the case of Dirichlet boundary
conditions, namely
yâ€²â€² + y + a sin y = h(t),
y(0) = 0 = y(Ï€),
and its analog for partial differential equations, has been the object, since the pioneering
papers of Ward [128] using critical point theory, and of Schaaf and Schmitt [118] using
global bifurcation, of a number of studies by Arcoya, CaÃ±ada, Lupo, Roca, Ruiz, Solimini,
UreÃ±a and others. References can be found in [82] and in the more recent contributions
[28â€“31]. This problem, which has both deep analogies and strong differences with the
periodic boundary value problem for the forced pendulum, will not be considered here.
Finally, in order to keep the number of references at a reasonable level, we have only
quoted the papers whose results are directly mentioned in this survey. Further bibliograph-
ical information can be found in [82].

Equation (13) has no periodic solution of the second kind and two heteroclinic orbits if

The effective determination of c0 is an important and delicate problem.

3.5. The degeneracy problem
The degeneracy problem for the T -periodic solutions of Equation (14), which is still open,
consists in proving or disproving the existence of some h such that mËœh = MËœh. Here is the

5.2. Chaotic dynamics
We ï¬rst recall the deï¬nition of chaotic dynamics.
DEFINITION 17. Equation (23) displays chaotic dynamics if
(i) the solutions of Equation (23) depend sensitively on the initial conditions;
(ii) Equation (23) has inï¬nitely many periodic solutions with diverging periods;
(iii) Equation (23) has an uncountable number of bounded, nonperiodic solutions;

almost periodic solutions. A special case of his results is the following proposition.

WaË™zewski method and Conley index
593
1. Introduction
The main subject of this note is the retract method introduced by Tadeusz WaË™zewski. It
is a method of proving the existence of solutions which remain in a given set and refers
to differential equations describing some evolution in time. The sets under consideration
should satisfy the condition â€œall egress points are strictâ€ or its less restrictive variant. Now
they are called WaË™zewski sets. The method is based on theorems which roughly assert that
there is a solution contained a WaË™zewski set for all positive values of time if the subset of
egress points is not a retract of the whole set (which explains the name of the method). If,
moreover, the set is compact then its invariant part (i.e., the set of full solutions contained
in it) is nonempty. For isolating blocks, i.e., compact WaË™zewski sets which do not contain
any full solutions intersecting their boundaries, Charles Conley discovered a homotopical
invariant which provides a quantitative information on their invariant parts. It is called
the Conley index. The Conley index theory, both from a point of view of continuous and
discrete-time dynamical systems, was presented by Mischaikow and Mrozek in Chapter 9
of Handbook of Dynamical Systems, vol. 2, within the current series of handbooks edited
by Elsevier Science B.V. (see [50]).
In this note we describe the WaË™zewski method in details and provide an information on
foundations of the Conley index theory which directly relates to the method and essentially
does not overlap with the exposition of Mischaikow and Mrozek. We begin with a short
introduction to the method and to the theory related to the index in a historical context.
1.1. Historical background of topological methods
The modern understanding of mechanics begins since the fundamental research of Newton
in the XVII century. In order to formulate the rules of motion, Newton introduced the con-
cept of differential equation. The equations which appear in mechanics belong mainly to
the class of ordinary differential equations. They are characterized by a distinguished para-
meter interpreted as time and, if some regularity conditions are imposed, the initial data de-
termine the whole solution. It was clear from the beginning that in general one cannot ï¬nd
analytical formulas for such solutions. Instead of rigorous description, numerical meth-
ods usually provide satisfactory approximations of solutions in bounded time-intervals.
Possibility of calculation of such approximations contributed mainly to the successful de-
velopment of applied mechanics.
However, numerical methods fail in general if one is interested in the global behavior
of the solution, i.e., in the whole domain, up to the left and right range of time of its
existence. For a given initial data, usually it is impossible to determine whether the solution
represents a periodic motion and to predict the asymptotic behavior at the limits of its
existence. As it was observed by Henri PoincarÃ© at the end of the XIX century, the behavior
of solutions can be very complicated and have a chaotic character, hence one cannot expect
to determine the full information on the dynamics generated by a given equation. Even a
proof of the existence of a solution with prescribed behavior (periodic, almost-periodic,
bounded, chaotic, satisfying some boundary conditions, etc.) is usually a difï¬cult task.

594
R. Srzednicki
PoincarÃ© initiated systematic studies on the global understanding of solutions and dy-
namics, which are known under the name of qualitative theory of differential equations, or,
in a more general context, theory of dynamical systems. Besides analytical arguments he
used methods of topology and algebra. Research on limit cycles and indexes of zeroes of
planar vector ï¬elds, periodic solutions of Hamiltonian systems (in particular, based on his
â€œtwist theoremâ€), and stability of the Solar system belong to his most known results on that
ï¬eld. He also contributed essentially in the development of variational methods applied to
boundary value problems.
One of the greatest achievements of PoincarÃ© was the introduction of algebraic topology
(called by him â€œanalysis situsâ€). Among the results which were proved by its applica-
tion, there were the ï¬xed point theorems of L.E.J. Brouwer (1912) and Salomon Lefschetz
(1923) which found natural applications in the qualitative theory of differential equations.
Brouwer introduced also the concept of the degree of a vector-ï¬eld. A related notion of the
ï¬xed point index was invented later by Jean Leray. The Brouwer ï¬xed point theorem and
the degree were generalized to the inï¬nite-dimensional case by Juliusz Schauder in 1930
and, respectively, by Leray and Schauder in 1934. Together with variational methods, they
form the main tools in proofs of results on existence of solutions of initial and boundary
value problems in nonlinear differential equations. The idea of their application consists
in suitable choice of an operator acting on a function space in which the original problem
reduces to the existence of its ï¬xed point or its zero. In variational methods, the existence
of a solution of the problem is equivalent to the existence of a critical point of a suitable
functional. An essential progress in development of these methods were done by Marston
Morse in 1925 who invented the theory of critical points which now bears his name and by
Lusternik and Schnirelmann by their research on the concept of category in 1930. It seems
that the next major achievement in topological approach to differential equations was done
by Tadeusz WaË™zewski (1896â€“1972) by introducing the retract method in the middle of the
twentieth century.
1.2. An outline of the WaË™zewski method in a historical context
The following deï¬nition provides the notion of a retract introduced by Karol Borsuk in the
paper [13] from 1931. Let X be a topological space and let A be its subset.
DEFINITION 1.1. A continuous map r :X â†’A such that r(a) = a for every a âˆˆA is
called a retraction. A is called a retract of X if there exists a retraction X â†’A. A con-
tinuous map r :X â†’A is called a strong deformation retraction if it is equal to the map
x 
â†’h(x,1), where h:X Ã— [0,1] â†’X is a continuous map such that h(x,0) = x and
h(x,1) âˆˆA for every x âˆˆX, and h(a,t) = a for every a âˆˆA and t âˆˆ[0,1]. A is called a
strong deformation retract of X if there exists a strong deformation retraction X â†’A.
Obviously, a strong deformation retract is also a retract and a retract of a connected
set is also connected. Moreover, it is well known that the Brouwer ï¬xed point theorem is
equivalent to the fact that the unit sphere Snâˆ’1 in Rn is not a retract of the closed unit
ball Bn.

Denote by E the set of egress points. There is a distinguished subset V âˆ—of V consisting

Let Y âŠ‚E and let Z âŠ‚V âˆªY. The main theorem [85, Theorem 1] is the following:
WA Ë™ZEWSKI THEOREM. If all egress points are strict egress points and
â€¢ Z âˆ©Y is a retract of Y,
â€¢ Z âˆ©Y is not a retract of Z

In particular, the second possibility in the conclusion is trivially excluded if Y = E
(compare [85, Theorem 2]). If we exchange egress points by ingress points in the statement
of the theorem, we obtain a result on the existence of a negative semitrajectory.
Originally, the WaË™zewski method (or the retract method) consisted in applications of the
theorem in proofs of the existence of solutions representing some special properties, usu-
ally referred to its asymptotic behavior. As it was indicated in [85], a suitable choice of the
sets Z and Y leads also to proofs of the existence of solutions of some two-point boundary
value problems. In [85], WaË™zewski pointed out also how to drop the assumption on the
uniqueness of the Cauchy problem if the considered set Z is compact and V is a polyfa-
cial set, which roughly means that it is described by some strong inequalities (compare
Sections 3.1 and 3.2).

The WaË™zewski theorem was announced also in [86,87], and later in the proceedings of
the Congress of Mathematicians in Amsterdam [89]. Its proof follows easily from a lemma
which asserts the continuity of the consequent map V âˆ—âˆªE â†’E provided the assumption

V âˆ—âˆªE âˆ‹x â†’Ïƒ(x) âˆˆ[0,âˆ)
is continuous.
The lemma has important consequences for the homotopy theory methods in differential
equations. At present, the name â€œWaË™zewski methodâ€ refers also to arguments applying
WaË™zewski lemma. Complete proofs of the WaË™zewski theorem and related results will be
presented in Section 2.3.
In the years after publication of [85], the WaË™zewski method was intensively developed
and applied by many authors. Both the assumptions on retraction and egress points in the
WaË™zewski theorem were modiï¬ed. Improved versions of the theorem using variants of the
notion of strong deformation retract were given, among others, in the papers [1,58,62]; the
proofs of those versions were based on the WaË™zewski lemma. In Section 2.3, we provide
examples of such results. On the other hand, in [11] Bielecki observed that all results
concerning the WaË™zewski method which are based on the hypothesis â€œall egress points
are strictâ€ can be directly strengthen if strict egress points are replaced by strong egress
points. (In the above notation, an egress point x âˆˆE is called a strong egress point if for
every t > 0 there exists 0 < s < t such that Ï†(x,s) /âˆˆV .) Later, in [20] (and also in [21])
Charles Conley (1933â€“1984) presented a version of the WaË™zewski theorem with a more
general and convenient form of that assumption. He introduced the notion of the exit set
W âˆ’of an arbitrary set W (in a similar way as we deï¬ned above the set of strong egress
points), and with its use, he deï¬ned the concept of WaË™zewski set. We provide its deï¬nition
later in Section 2.1. At this moment we mention that it is particularly easy to check in one
case: if W and W âˆ’are closed then W satisï¬es the deï¬nition of a WaË™zewski set. Moreover,
referring to our previous consideration, the set V âˆªE is a WaË™zewski set provided each
egress point is a strong egress point; in that case E is its exit set. The main feature of
[21] was the observation that the WaË™zewski lemma extends to WaË™zewski sets: the escape-
time function Ïƒ :x 
â†’Ïƒ(x) deï¬ned for points of W such that their positive semitrajectory
leaves W, is continuous. (Here, similarly as before, Ïƒ(x) denotes the ï¬rst time in which
the semitrajectory of x hits W âˆ’.) Our presentation of the results related to the WaË™zewski
theorem in Section 2.3 is inspired by the ideas of Conley.

1.3. On the origin of the Conley index theory
The WaË™zewski theorem, like the Schauder ï¬xed point theorem is an existence result. Com-
plementary to the Schauder theorem, the Lerayâ€“Schauder degree and the ï¬xed point in-
dex provide a quantitative information on the number of solutions. In some sense, similar
complementary quantitative information on solutions given by the WaË™zewski method is
provided by the Conley index, a topological invariant related to WaË™zewski sets of a special
form, called isolating blocks. By an isolating block we mean a compact subset B of the
phase space of a local ï¬‚ow Ï† such that B = intB and every x âˆˆâˆ‚B is either a strict egress
point, or a strict ingress point, or a point of outward tangency of intB (its deï¬nition is
stated in Section 7.1 in a slightly more general form). An example of isolating block is
shown on Figure 1. For an isolating block B, its exit set Bâˆ’consists of all strict egress and
outward tangency points. Because of the compactness of B, if some positive semitrajectory
is contained in B then its limit set is nonempty and also contained in B. Since the limit set
is invariant, it is contained in the invariant part of B
Inv(B) := x âˆˆB: Ï†(x,t) âˆˆB âˆ€t
which is nonempty in this case. The set Inv(B) is an example of an isolated invariant set,
i.e., a compact set which is maximal invariant in some of its neighborhood. (Obviously,
the block itself is such a neighborhood for Inv(B).) In the above sense, isolating blocks
have several other nice properties due to symmetry with respect to reversing the time-axis.
(Sometimes they are deï¬ned only as compact WaË™zewski sets which are simultaneously
isolating neighborhoods.)
The ï¬rst extensive research on isolating blocks for smooth ï¬‚ows appeared in 1971 in the
paper [22] by Conley and Richard Easton. In that paper an important theorem was proved:
FIRST CONLEY THEOREM. Each isolated invariant set is an invariant part of some iso-
lating block.
Also in 1971, Conley announced another important theorem (compare [19]):
SECOND CONLEY THEOREM. If S is an isolated invariant set then the homotopy type
[B/Bâˆ’,âˆ—] of the pointed space obtained from B by collapsing Bâˆ’to a point âˆ—, does not
depend on the choice of an isolating block B such that S = Inv(B).
(We refer to Section 5.2 for rigorous deï¬nitions of the notions involved in that state-
ment.) A proof of the second Conley theorem appeared later in [18] (on the Ë‡Cech cohomol-
ogy level only) and in [21] in the full generality. Both the theorems ensure the correctness
of the following
DEFINITION 1.3. The Conley index of an isolated invariant set S, denoted by h(Ï†,S), is
deï¬ned as the homotopy type [B/Bâˆ’,âˆ—] for an arbitrary isolating block B having S as the
invariant part.

WaË™zewski method and Conley index
601
In the Conleyâ€™s publications the index appeared under the names homotopy index and
generalized Morse index. The origin of the later name is the Morse theory. If f :M â†’R
is a Morse function and Ï† is the (local) ï¬‚ow generated by the gradient equation
Ë™x = âˆ’âˆ‡f (x)
then each critical point x0 of f is also an isolated invariant set for Ï† and its Conley index
h(Ï†,{x0}) is equal to the homotopy type of the pointed k-dimensional sphere Sk, where k
is the Morse index of x0. (Recall that the Morse index is deï¬ned as the number of negative
eigenvalues of the Hessian of f at x0.) Thanks to the above relation between the indexes,
some results of the Morse theory were extended to the theory of isolated invariant sets.
A simple application of the WaË™zewski lemma leads to the conclusion that if h(Ï†,S)
is nontrivial (i.e., it is not the homotopy type of a one-point space) then S is nonempty.
The converse is not true in general (see Example 9.5) and in this respect the Conley index
is not a better tool then the WaË™zewski method. The Conley index has the additivity and
multiplicativity properties, which explain in which sense it â€œcountsâ€ solutions in S. The
main advantage of the index is its continuation property: two isolated invariant sets (with
respect to possibly different ï¬‚ows) which can be linked by a kind of homotopy, have the
same Conley indices. This property is in an analogy to the homotopy properties of the
Brouwer and Lerayâ€“Schauder degrees, and the ï¬xed point index. It enables calculation of
the index in a complicated system by its continuation to a simpler one.
1.4. Review of the current exposition
Our exposition is rather self-contained; we present almost all necessary deï¬nitions and we
prove a majority of the stated results, although in a few cases we provide sketches of proofs
only.
In Section 2, we deï¬ne the WaË™zewski set (Deï¬nition 2.4), state its main properties
(Lemma 2.1) and state strong versions of the WaË™zewski theorem: Theorem 2.1 valid for
local semiï¬‚ows and Theorem 2.2, based on the notion of quasi-isotopic deformation re-
tract (Deï¬nition 2.7), valid for local ï¬‚ows. Section 3 presents methods of construction
of WaË™zewski sets for ordinary differential equations. In particular, so-called polyfacial sets
and generalized polyfacial sets are deï¬ned (Deï¬nitions 3.1 and 3.4). Moreover, a version of
the WaË™zewski theorem for equations without the uniqueness property and differential inclu-
sions is stated (Theorem 3.1). The WaË™zewski method for local semiï¬‚ows generated by re-
tarded functional differential equations is described in Section 4, where the corresponding
main results are Theorems 4.1 and 4.2. Some topological concepts are recalled in Section 5.
They include the notions of the quotient space (Deï¬nition 5.1), the absolute and pointed
homotopy types (Deï¬nition 5.2), absolute neighborhood retract (Deï¬nition 5.3), relative
Lusternikâ€“Schnirelmann category (Deï¬nition 5.6), and cup length (Deï¬nition 5.9). More-
over, we recall the Lefschetz ï¬xed point theorem (Proposition 5.6) and properties of the
ï¬xed point index (Proposition 5.7). In Section 6, we provide some general results on prop-
erties of the sets of solutions given by the WaË™zewski method. In particular, Theorem 6.1
estimates their category and Theorem 6.2 is a result on the existence of stationary points.

602
R. Srzednicki
Section 7 presents the notion of isolating block (Deï¬nition 7.1) and its topological prop-
erties. The related results on the category (Theorem 7.1), exact sequences (Theorem 7.3),
cup-length (Theorem 7.4), stationary points of gradient-like local ï¬‚ows (Theorem 7.5), and
ï¬xed point index (Theorem 7.6) are given. Moreover, we deï¬ne the notion of an isolating
segment (Deï¬nition 7.4) and we prove Theorem 7.7, a related to that notion result on the
ï¬xed point index of the evolutionary map. In Section 8, we present three applications of
results stated in previous sections. The ï¬rst of them, Theorem 8.1, generalizes a result
of Perron on linear equations, the second one is a result on the existence of solutions of
two-point boundary value problems under the classical Bernsteinâ€“Nagumo condition (The-
orem 8.2), and the last one is a result on the existence of chaotic dynamics (Theorem 8.3).
An introduction to the Conley index theory is contained in Section 9. Deï¬nition 9.1 pro-
vides the notion of an isolated invariant set, Theorems 9.1 and 9.2 of Conley lead to the
deï¬nition of the index, and properties of the index are stated in Theorems 9.3 and 9.4.
Some calculations of the index are given in Propositions 9.1 and 9.2, and an example of
its applications is given in the proof of Proposition 9.3. Finally, in Section 9.4 we indicate
extensions and improvements of the Conley index.
The bibliography contains positions which usually directly refer to topics presented in
this note and by far it does not pretend to be the complete list of books and articles on
the WaË™zewski method and the Conley index. We point out that biographical information
on Tadeusz WaË™zewski and Charles Conley can be found in the articles [54] and, respec-
tively, [47].

2.3. Versions of the WaË™zewski theorem
The WaË™zewski theorem appears in the literature in various forms and each of them is a
direct application of Lemma 2.1 stated above, especially its part (iii) (i.e., the WaË™zewski
lemma). Our purpose is to formulate the theorem in a form convenient for applications. In
fact, we present two theorems. The ï¬rst one is a direct generalization of the main theorems
of [85] and [20] obtained in a possibly most â€œeconomicâ€ way. It is sufï¬cient for a great
majority of applications existing in the literature. However, as we show in a relatively
simple example, it is sometimes convenient to have its stronger version and such a version
will be presented at the end of the current section. In any case we should extend the notion
of a strong deformation retract given in Deï¬nition 1.1. To this purpose we follow the ideas
from the papers [58,62].
Assume that X is a topological space and A and B are subsets of X such that A âŠ‚B.
DEFINITION 2.6. A is called a strong deformation retract of B in X if there exists a
continuous map h:B Ã— [0,1] â†’X (for which we also write ht(x) instead of h(x,t)) such
that
(a) h(x,0) = x for every x âˆˆB,
(b) h(x,t) = x for every x âˆˆA and t âˆˆ[0,1],
(c) h1(B) âŠ‚A.
Obviously, in the case B = X, A is a strong deformation retract of B in the usual sense
(see Deï¬nition 1.1). Moreover, if A is a strong deformation retract of B in X then A is a
retract of B, if Xâ€² âŠƒX then A is also a strong deformation retract of B in Xâ€², and if A
is a strong deformation retract of X then A is also a strong deformation retract of B in X
for every B such that A âŠ‚B âŠ‚X. A comparison among various types of retracts can be
visualized on Figure 4. Here X is the grey rectangle with a hole, A is its bottom edge, and

3. WaË™zewski method in ordinary differential equations and inclusions
Abstract local ï¬‚ows and semiï¬‚ows, for which we describe the WaË™zewski method in Sec-
tion 2, arise in the theory of differential equations. Here we present how to construct
WaË™zewski sets in ordinary differential equations and give some extensions of the method
to equations which do not generate local semiï¬‚ows.
3.1. Polyfacial sets
A usual construction of WaË™zewski sets is based on existence of functions which behave

3.2. Equations without the uniqueness property and differential inclusions
Using polyfacial sets, in this section we extend the WaË™zewski method to the case in which
the vector-ï¬eld v :M â†’T M does not satisfy the uniqueness property of the initial value
problem (1.1), (1.2). Since it does not involve any essential difï¬culty, we will extend the
WaË™zewski method even further: we will consider differential inclusions. The idea of an ex-
tension to equations without uniqueness comes from the original paper [85] of WaË™zewski,
while the extension to differential inclusions was initiated by Bielecki in [12] (he used the
term paratingent equations). Our presentation is based on the Bieleckiâ€™s approach.
As in Section 3.1, we assume that M is Riemannian manifold with a given metric. Let F
be a multivalued vector-ï¬eld on M, i.e., for every x âˆˆM we assign a nonempty compact
and convex set F(x) âŠ‚TxM. In what follows we assume that F is upper semi-continuous,
i.e., for every x âˆˆM and every Îµ there exists a neighborhood U of x such that if y âˆˆU
then F(y) is contained in the Îµ-neighborhood N(F(x),Îµ) of F(x) in T M. (In particular,
every single-valued continuous vector-ï¬eld has that property.) By a solution of a differen-
tial inclusion
Ë™x âˆˆF(x)
(3.12)
we mean an absolutely continuous mapping t 
â†’x(t) deï¬ned in some interval such that
Ë™x(t) âˆˆF(x(t)) for almost every t. We assume also that the domain of x is maximal, i.e.,
the solution is saturated.
Below we assume that V be a polyfacial set determined by {â„“i,mj}, i = 1,...,p, j =
1,...,q, p + q â©¾1, and the sets Li, Mj, and let E are given by, respectively, (3.1), (3.2),
and (3.6).

In the sequel we assume that V is a polyfacial set for (3.12). Our aim is to prove the
following extension of the WaË™zewski theorem, which essentially were given in [12]:
THEOREM 3.1. Let Y âŠ‚E and Z âŠ‚V âˆªY. Assume that Z and E \ Y are compact and Y
is not a quasi-isotopic deformation retract of Z âˆªY in V âˆªE. Then there exists a solution
x of (3.12) such that x(0) âˆˆZ and

â€¢ either x(t) âˆˆV for all t â©¾0
â€¢ or there exists a t0 > 0 such that x(t) âˆˆV if t âˆˆ[0,t0] and x(t0) âˆˆE \ Y.
PROOF. We will base on the results stated in [4], although they concern the case M = Rn
only. In the case of an arbitrary manifold M they can be stated in a similar way. Let vn be
a sequence of locally Lipschitzean vector-ï¬elds such that their graphs in T M approximate
the graph of F and preserve the strong inequalities (3.3) and (3.4) (compare [4, Theo-
rem 1.12.1]). By Theorem 2.2, for each n either there exists a point xn âˆˆZ such that the
solution of the equation
Ë™x = vn(x)
starting at xn remains in V or there exists an yn and tn > 0 such that the solution starting
at yn remains in V for t âˆˆ[0,tn) and yn(tn) âˆˆE \ Y. At least one of the sequences {xn}
and {yn} must be inï¬nite. An accumulation point of that inï¬nite sequence has the required
properties (compare First Proof of Theorem 2.1.3 in [4]; observe moreover that the time t0
in the conclusion is positive since the distance between Z and E \ Y is nonzero).

We get the following corollary as an immediate consequence of the theorem in the case

COROLLARY 3.1. If H(V âˆªE,E) Ì¸= 0, where H is the singular homology functor with
coefï¬cients in a given ring, then there exists a solution x of (3.12) such that x(t) âˆˆV for
all t â©¾0.
PROOF. Indeed, by the assumption there exists a singular chain c in V âˆªE which is a
homologically nontrivial cycle with respect to the pair (V âˆªE,E), hence its support Z :=
|c| cannot be continuously deformed to E. Thus Z is compact and satisï¬es the assumption
of Theorem 3.1, hence the result follows.

The questions concerning the existence of solutions contained in a given set are im-
portant in the theory of differential inclusions; the area of research related to them bears
the name viability theory (compare [3,4]). In that theory, a set W is called viable at x0 if
x0 âˆˆW and there exists a solution x with x(0) = x0 and x(t) âˆˆW for all t â©¾0.
Apart from the Bieleckiâ€™s paper, WaË™zewski-type theorems for equations without unique-
ness and differential inclusions appeared in several publications, compare for example [6â€“
9,40,43]. Opposite to the approximation argument in the above proof, a purely topological
approach based on set-valued retractions was frequently presented and the obtained re-
sults were limited in practice to questions of lack of connectedness. Recently, in the paper
[35], Gabor and Quincampoix applied homology theory methods for admissible multival-
ued mappings (see [33]) to obtain stronger results in that topological setting. In particular,
[35] contains a theorem similar to Corollary 3.1 valid for closed sets which resemble the
WaË™zewski ones. We state it below.

4. WaË™zewski method for retarded functional differential equations
Now we consider local semiï¬‚ows generated by retarded functional differential equations
(RFDEs). We provide results concerning the WaË™zewski method for those equations which
go beyond direct substitutions of the abstract WaË™zewski-type theorems from Section 2 to
those semiï¬‚ows.
4.1. Local semiï¬‚ows generated by RFDEs
Let M be a Riemannian manifold. For each continuous function x :J â†’M, where J âŠ‚

4.2. WaË™zewski-type theorems for RFDEs
Our presentation of the basic results concerning the WaË™zewski method in Section 2.3 was
purely topological, hence it also directly applies to local semiï¬‚ows described in the previ-
ous section. However, since their phase-spaces are inï¬nite-dimensional, usually the theo-
rems given in Section 2.3 have limited applications, at least because the sphere in such a
space is a retract of the ball. Therefore one should provide separate WaË™zewski-type theo-
rems more suitable for retarded functional differential equations. To this aim we will follow
an idea in the paper [67] by Rybakowski. Actually, it was preceded by [57], in which con-
sidered conditions were too restrictive, and [49], where the idea later used in [67] appeared
in a special case. We will not provide Rybakowskiâ€™s approach in the full generality, be-
cause it would require the introduction of several new concepts, but we rather concentrate
on results which can be directly used in applications.

5. Some topological concepts
In order to state variants of the WaË™zewski theorem, we have already deï¬ned the notion of
retract and its modiï¬cations. In this section we recall several other topological notions and
results which will be used in description of properties of the sets of solutions obtained by
the WaË™zewski method.
5.1. Topological pairs, quotient spaces, and pointed spaces
By a topological pair we mean a pair (X,A) consisting of a topological space X and its
subset A. If A is closed in X then (X,A) is a called a closed pair. If x0 âˆˆX, we frequently
write (X,x0) for the topological pair (X,{x0}). Let (X,A) and (Y,B) be topological pairs.
We write f :(X,A) â†’(Y,B) if f is continuous map X â†’Y and f (A) âŠ‚B.
Now we recall the notion of quotient space. We impose a special attention to the case in
which the empty space is involved. Let (X,A) be a topological pair.
DEFINITION 5.1. The quotient space X/A is the set whose elements are all points of X\A
and the set A (denoted by [A] in order to avoid confusions), i.e.,

direct sum topology of X and the one-point space {[âˆ…]}. In particular, âˆ…/âˆ…is equal to {[âˆ…]}.
Since [A] is distinguished in X/A in a canonical way, in order to simplify the notation, for
an arbitrary pair (X,A) we write shortly (X/A,âˆ—) instead of (X/A,[A]).
For presentation of results involving quotient spaces we use the Ë‡Cech cohomology func-

5.2. Homotopy types
Recall that maps f,g :X â†’Y are homotopic (denoted f â‰ƒg) if for some continuous map

DEFINITION 5.2. We say that topological spaces X and Y have the same homotopy type
(and we write X â‰ƒY) if for some maps f :X â†’Y and g :Y â†’X (called homotopy equiv-

5.3. Absolute neighborhood retracts
We recall the topological notions of absolute and Euclidean neighborhood retracts.
DEFINITION 5.3 (compare [14,33]). A metrizable space X is called an absolute neigh-
borhood retract (shortly: ANR) if there is an open set U in a normed space E and a map
h:X â†’E which is a homeomorphism onto its image h(X) such that h(X) is a retract
of U.

630
R. Srzednicki
REMARK 5.3. There is an equivalent deï¬nition: A metrizable space X is an ANR if and
only if for each closed subset A of a metrizable space W and every continuous map
f :A â†’X there exists a neighborhood U of A in W and a continuous map F :U â†’X
such that F|A = f (compare [14, Theorem IV(4.2)(ii)]).
We refer to [14] for other properties of ANRs.
DEFINITION 5.4 (compare [28]). A metrizable space X is called an Euclidean neighbor-
hood retract (shortly: ENR) if there is an n âˆˆN, an open set U in Rn, and a map h:X â†’Rn
which is a homeomorphism onto its image h(X) such that h(X) is a retract of U.
The class of ENRs coincides with the class of locally compact, separable, and ï¬nite-
dimensional ANRs. Examples of ENRs include all compact polyhedra and manifolds with
boundary. The Hilbert cube is a compact ANR which is not an ENR.

EXAMPLE 7.5. The following fact was essential in the proof of an Arnoldâ€™s conjecture by

REMARK 7.2. Results on the existence and the number of critical points of functionals are
essential in variational methods. Since the spaces considered in those methods are inï¬nite-
dimensional, usually direct applications of results based on algebraic topology fail there.
For some functionals it is possible, however, to pass to a ï¬nite dimension by the saddle-
point reduction due to Amann and Zehnder (compare [2]). In particular, it was applied in
the paper [23] to reduce the initial problem to calculation of the number of critical points
inside the isolating block mentioned in Example 7.5.

using the notion of ï¬xed point index.

8. Selected applications of the WaË™zewski method
We provide some applications of the results stated above. We begin with an application
to problems concerning asymptotic properties of solutions, then we present a proof of a
classical result on the existence of solutions of two-point boundary value problems for a
second-order equation, and ï¬nally we state a result on the existence of a kind of chaotic
dynamics.

WaË™zewski method and Conley index
659
8.1. Asymptotic solutions
The most natural applications of the WaË™zewski method refer to the existence of solutions
remaining in a given set; for instance, theorems on bounded solutions can be provided in
this way. If the considered sets in the extended phase space contract as time tends to in-
ï¬nity, the obtained solutions represent the corresponding asymptotic properties. There are
many results of this type in the literature. In particular, theorems on solutions which tend to
constant mappings are contained, for example, in [48,66,84,88] (the result in [48] is repro-
duced also in [65]) and results on asymptotic coincidence of solutions of two systems are,
among others, in [45,53,55,56,82]. Some other asymptotic results for ordinary equations
are given in [10,25,39,41,46,69,83], for retarded differential equations in [27,80], for par-
tial differential equations of the ï¬rst order in [59,60], and for the second order in [61]. For
an illustration of this kind of applications of the WaË™zewski method, here we provide a proof
of an asymptotic result for a linear equation. Let A = (aij) and B = (bij) be continuous
real (n Ã— n)-matrix-valued functions and we consider an equation

9. Conley index
Using the notion of isolating block we present the deï¬nition of the Conley index and pro-
vide its basic properties. In particular, we indicate its relation to the WaË™zewski method. We
do not present more advanced topics of the theory of the index; for them we refer to [50].
9.1. Isolated invariant sets and the Conley index
Let X be a metrizable locally compact space and let Ï† be a local ï¬‚ow on X.
DEFINITION 9.1. A compact set S âŠ‚X is called an isolated invariant set provided there
exists U, a neighborhood of S, such that S = Inv(U). Such an U is called an isolating
neighborhood for S.
EXAMPLE 9.1. Let A be a real n Ã— n-matrix, let U be an open neighborhood of 0 in Rn,
and let f :U â†’Rn be a C1-class function. Denote by Ï† the local ï¬‚ow on U generated by
the equation
Ë™x = Ax + f (x).
Assume that
f (x) = o


as x â†’0

and there are no purely imaginary eigenvalues of A. Then the one-point set {0} is an iso-

neighborhood of 0 to the ï¬‚ow generated by the linear vector-ï¬eld x

have any bounded solutions except of the trivial one.
In an obvious way Example 9.1 generalizes to a stationary point of the local ï¬‚ow gener-

DEFINITION 9.2. A stationary point x0 âˆˆM is called hyperbolic of index k if the dif-
ferential dx0v does not have eigenvalues on the imaginary axis and there are exactly k
eigenvalues (counted with multiplicities) with the positive real part.
It follows that if x0 is a hyperbolic point then {x0} is an isolated invariant set.

is an isolated invariant set and U is its isolating neighborhood. It follows that isolated
critical points of a smooth functional g :M â†’R are isolated invariant sets of the local
ï¬‚ow generated by (6.1).

9.2. Properties of the Conley index
At ï¬rst we provide the deï¬nition of the continuation (i.e., homotopy) relation between
isolated invariant sets. Assume that Ï† and Ïˆ are local ï¬‚ows on a metrizable locally compact

DEFINITION 9.3. We say that pairs (Ï†,S) and (Ïˆ,T ) are related by continuation (denoted
(Ï†,S) â‰ƒ(Ïˆ,T )) if there exists a local ï¬‚ow Î¦ on X Ã— [0,1], an isolated invariant set Sâˆ—

The relation of continuity between isolated invariant sets provides no information on

connected set can split by continuation into a nonconnected one as we see in the following

By the example, the Conley index is a direct generalization of the Morse index (up to
the correspondence k vs. Î£k): it also applies to degenerate isolated critical points of a
functional, since they are isolated invariant sets as we have mentioned in Example 9.2. In
spite of the fact that functionals used in variational methods operate in inï¬nite-dimensional
spaces, hence not locally compact ones, the Conley index ï¬nds its application there thanks
to the saddle-point reduction method from [2] (compare also Remark 7.2).
Let Î“ be a nontrivial periodic orbit of Ï†, i.e., the trajectory Ï†(x) of a periodic, non-
stationary point x. It is called hyperbolic of index k if dxP , the differential at x of the
PoincarÃ© map P associated to a section of Î“ in a neighborhood of x does not have eigen-
values on the unit circle and there are exactly k eigenvalues (counted with multiplicities)
outside of the unit disc. Then the unstable manifold W u(Î“ ) of Î“ is of dimension k + 1
and we call Î“ untwisted (respectively, twisted) provided W u(Î“ ) is orientable (respectively,
nonorientable).

â–¡
9.4. Concluding remarks
We provided only basic facts concerning the Conley index; a more comprehensive intro-
ductions to that notion are given in [21] and [70, Chapters 22 and 23]. For some more
advanced topics we refer to [50], where the index or its generalizations are deï¬ned both for
continuous and discrete-time ï¬‚ows, and results related to attractorâ€“repealer pairs, Morse
decompositions, connection and transition matrices, singular isolating neighborhoods, and
computer assisted proofs are considered. Finally, we would like to mention some exten-
sions and modiï¬cations of the Conley index for the continuous-time local ï¬‚ows:
â€¢ An improvement due to Conley in which the index is a connected simple system gen-
erated by all blocks (and more generally, by all index pairs) for an isolated invariant
set S and connecting maps are naturally given by pushing along trajectories (compare
[21]).
â€¢ A structure of the module over Ë‡H âˆ—(X) for the cohomological Conley index, where X
is the phase space, and its generalization to the equivariant case due to Floer in [30].
â€¢ An inï¬nite-dimensional version given in [68], which applies to semilinear partial dif-
ferential equations with the linear parts generated by sectorial operators having com-
pact resolvents.
â€¢ Another inï¬nite-dimensional version deï¬ned in [36] for ï¬‚ows generated by vector-
ï¬elds of the form L + K in a Hilbert space, where L is a bounded linear Fredholm
operator and K is a completely continuous nonlinear operator. It particularly well ï¬ts
to results on the existence of critical points in variational problems.
â€¢ Multivalued versions given in [51] and, in a simpler case of equations without unique-
ness, in [44].
â€¢ The index over a base space deï¬ned in [52] which provides a better recognition of
isolated invariant sets then the index h in the case of noncontractible phase space. In
particular, it is nontrivial for the invariant part of the block considered in Example 9.5
if the knotted orbit is removed from the phase space.
